natural problem:
Find the real roots of
\[x^4 - 2x^3 - x + 2 = 0.\]
natural solution: We can factor the polynomial as \begin{align} x^4 - 2x^3 - x + 2 &= (x - 2) x^3 - (x - 2) \\ &= (x - 2)(x^3 - 1) \\ &= (x - 2)(x - 1)(x^2 + x + 1). \end{align}The quadratic factor $x^2 + x + 1$ has no real roots, so the real roots are $\boxed{1,2}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x powr 4 - 2 * x powr 3 - x + 2 = 0"
shows  "x = 1 \<or> x = 2"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the real roots of
\[x^4 - 2x^3 - x + 2 = 0.\] The final Answer is 1,2
 ### Proof
 We can factor the polynomial as \begin{align} x^4 - 2x^3 - x + 2 &= (x - 2) x^3 - (x - 2) \\ &= (x - 2)(x^3 - 1) \\ &= (x - 2)(x - 1)(x^2 + x + 1). \end{align}The quadratic factor $x^2 + x + 1$ has no real roots, so the real roots are $\boxed{1,2}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x powr 4 - 2 * x powr 3 - x + 2 = 0"
shows  "x = 1 \<or> x = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the real solutions to the equation $x^4 - 2x^3 - x + 2 = 0$. The possible solutions are $x = 1$ or $x = 2$.
